I suspect that nothing will convince you of truth unless it supports your notion of it.

 
 Funny, in essence, I just posted the exact same response to your 9/11 thread regarding your obvious version of truth.
 
 I opened my post with "Regardless of where the truth lies" and my point had nothing to do with which side I believed. My post was to point out the rather tenuous ground in believing the Saudi foreign affairs minister.
 
 I don't like Bush, that I freely admit, however, I consider all sources of info available, as US party affiliation means nothing to me. They're all crooked and they all lie, the hard part is wading through both side's BS to find the truth.
 
 I suspect the truth lies somewhere in the middle on this issue as well.
 
 Waxy
Ghost

Woodward's book sounds very interesting. I've not read it yet, but I plan to pick it up soon. His last book, 'Bush at War,' is supposed to be pretty unbiased, from what I've heard. Already though, 'Plan of Attack' is raising a lot of issues. The relationship between Powell and Cheney, and especially what Woodward claims is Cheney's 'hawkish' attitude towards Iraq, is specially important. Powell has denied this already, so we don't really know. And the thing about the oil deal with the Saudis? Woodward has already denied making that allegation...seems no one told John Kerry that he didn't say that...oh well.
 
 Woodward's book raises some points which people should look at and think about, but they have to remember to take it with a grain of salt, just like what the Bush administration is saying in response.
